- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

# Single element
```pwsh
PS> $arr = @(1)
PS> ConvertTo-Json -InputObject $arr -Compress # [1]
PS> $arr | ConvertTo-Json -Compress # 1
```

# Multiple elements
```pwsh
PS> $arr = @(1,2)
PS> ConvertTo-Json -InputObject $arr -Compress # [1,2]
PS> $arr | ConvertTo-Json -Compress # [1,2]
```

### Expected behavior
I expected the same behaviour from both of these lines when an array contains one item:
```pwsh
PS> $arr = @(1)
PS> ConvertTo-Json -InputObject $arr -Compress # [1]
PS> $arr | ConvertTo-Json -Compress # [1]
```


### Actual behavior
`ConvertTo-Json` with piped input converts a single element array to a string without array characters (`[]`).

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
This is a quirk of how the PowerShell pipeline works  

When you pipe an array to something, the array is enumerated and the members are sent
so 
`@(1 ) | command`   is the same as 
`1 | command`    
and 
`@(1,2,3) | command ` sends 3 ints not a 3-item array-object

`ConvertTo-Json -Compress -InputObject @(1)`  works differently, it _doesn't_ expand the array (and rightly so).   
This is an exception to the general rule  `$x | command` and `command | $x`  do the same thing

comments.author: johanredeploy
comments.body:
@jhoneill makes sense when you explain it.

So this is a workaround I guess?
```pwsh
$arr = @(1)
,$arr | ConvertTo-Json -Compress # [1]
```

I will either way restort to using `InputObject` in the future because this confused me for a fair while.

Still seems a bit inconsistent that multiple elements yields proper output when piping.

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
That should work  - I haven't tested it. 

When ConvertTo-JSON receives multiple objects it makes them an array so  a multi-element array become and an array again, but it can't tell if a single item started life in array.  This does create some inconsistencies, and if what you're outputting is an array which might have zero, one or many elements, it's a pain.

comments.body: From the point of view of representation in Json format, both results are valid. The conversion from json returns `[int64]`.
